channel.title: I want to program
channel.description:
Hey guys, i'm new to programming and I need to know what type i should use. Examples: HTML,JAVA ect.
What should I start of with? Also comment with the best program for begginers and what I should program first.

item.title: I want to program
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote="_s, post:62, topic:428346"]to all that are regurgitating horseshit, technically shell scripting is a form of declarative programming. typically in the shell you compose utilities operating on data to filter, manipulate or use said data, and the entry point could be regarded as the first invocation or statement within your script.

also note that the line between ‘scripting’ and programming is a faint line that is open to interpretation when you consider that most ‘scripting’ languages are programming languages in their own right. a much nicer term for the common notion of ‘scripting’ language is an embeddable/embedded or extension language.[/quote]
it is indeed faint, my description was very blah.

Read full topic

item.title: I want to program
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

to all that are regurgitating horseshit, technically shell scripting is a form of declarative programming. typically in the shell you compose utilities operating on data to filter, manipulate or use said data, and the entry point could be regarded as the first invocation or statement within your script.

also note that the line between ‘scripting’ and programming is a faint line that is open to interpretation when you consider that most ‘scripting’ languages are programming languages in their own right. a much nicer term for the common notion of ‘scripting’ language is an embeddable/embedded or extension language.

Read full topic

item.title: I want to program
item.dc:creator: @lemme_winks lemme_winks_
item.description:
@lemme_winks wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:60, topic:428346”][quote author=lemme_winks_ link=topic=531038.msg3891204#msg3891204 date=1326859274]

Yes. Writing anything for a computer to do is programming. Its just not advanced.

really, now? shell scripting is programming too? :rolleyes:

what do you consider the act of programming to be?
[/quote]
To be writing an application with an entry point or a module for said framework. Scripting would just be writing a set of instructions that gets interpreted (for example by a shell) - writing within a program to execute a very specific task.[/quote]

i agree. i just wanted you to elaborate a bit

Read full topic

item.title: I want to program
item.dc:creator: @lurviq lurviq
item.description:
@lurviq wrote:

A bit off topic but when i started programming (child level) i did BATCH.
Batch is commands for the command prompt, using basic variables and such.
Made password systems, quizzes and stuff. (This was when i was 9 years old.)

A batch file in notepad could look like

@Echo off
echo Hello World!
pause>nul
echo Press any key to continue!

Just thought i’d tell you

Read full topic

item.description:

[quote=“Omer_, post:2, topic:428350”][quote author=Repu link=topic=531038.msg3881272#msg3881272 date=1326049570]
I personally would begin with languages such as Ruby or Perl; there is no perfect beginner language however you could benefit by learning simple syntax and then heading over to languages such as Java (hope not), C/C++, C# etc.
[/quote]

“Hope not”
Why?[/quote]I personally do not like Java, however I do still use it occasionally.

item.title: I want to program
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“The Enforcer, post:35, topic:428346”][quote author=_s link=topic=531038.msg3879640#msg3879640 date=1325948214]

I followed the soul’s recources and for C++ it said start of with ‘Hello World’
Is that incorrect? heres the code.

// my first program in C++

#include
using namespace std;

int main ()
{
cout << “Hello World!”;
return 0;
}

using namespace std;

the problem with using this is not performance related. however, it does show that you could care less about organization and also documenting your code. i would prefer doing this:

#include <string> // for std::string
using std::string; // essentially make it visible

if you’re dealing with header files, show that you give a fuck, and an include guard:

app.hpp

#ifndef _APP_HPP
#define _APP_HPP

// a bit extra
#pragma once

#include <string>

extern std::string hello();

#endif // _APP_HPP

app.cpp

#include "app.hpp"

using std::string;

string hello()
{
    return "hello";
}

if you are a bad-ass:

std::cout << "hello" << std::endl; // print "hello" and flush the output buffer

other than that there was never a problem in your code, really. great job. sorry for the rant to a beginner about something really small. it does make a difference.
[/quote]how using the whole standard namespace hints at poor organisation i do not know, it’s just preference. so many people use the whole namespace anyway that it’s never going to cause you any problems in using it since almost everyone knows better than to introduce a class named exactly like one in the std namespace and scare the user when he’s used both namespaces and there’s a name resolution conflict. also, i think from anyone who isn’t a Java programmer’s perspective, a wall of used classes at the top is ugly.

btw he shouldn’t need a header for a single file. nothing is ever going to include it (i mean, who the fuck has a main.h anyway) so it’s completely excessive.

Some C++ programmers are purists and always write std::. When using MSVC++ it’s also nicer to look at Intellisense when it only lists members of the standard namespace, not everything that’s in the global one. Also, you should never declare anything with ‘using’ in a header file - not very nice towards those who include it. This means that in header files you’ll have to write std:: everywhere. You could then do ‘using namespace std;’ in the cpp files, but are you really going to make your function definitions different from the prototypes to write just a little less?[/quote]personally i’m a namespace purist (std:: everywhere plZ!1), but i think it’s also common sense to not put a ‘using’ in the header file. as for making the prototypes and the actual implementation different, i’m fairly indifferent to it for as long as it’s clear.

@lemme_winks_: yes, what you prefer, of course, it’s all preference. let a programmer do what he wants in his file, whether it be full qualification, using or using namespace. it’s not bad because of your preference, it’s just your preference. there are problems with using a whole namespace, but there can also be problems with just using classes in the case that you’re using so much of the namespace that it uses up the best part of the screen just for 'using’s.

Read full topic

item.title: I want to program
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

He’s saying there’s little reason to use using directives, or using declarations for that matter.

Read full topic

item.title: I want to program
item.dc:creator: @lemme_winks lemme_winks_
item.description:
@lemme_winks wrote:

iKilem:

How does what you said to _s address what The Enforcer was saying?

you are writing a little less, but you are still showing what you are going to be using. this is strictly a personal preference, and a rant about what the cons are while using a whole namespace rather than little parts of it or accessing classes/functions directly. this is similar/and a summary to what i said to _s

the reason why i prefer one over the other is because when you are using the ambiguous "using namespace std" (which is considerably bad practice), you aren't telling anyone else or yourself what exactly you are going to be using--correct me if i'm wrong, but explicit instruction is essential while programming.

Read full topic
